entry.title: Extensibility in the Age of AI: Why ABCD Is Easier (and Smarter) Than You Think
entry.content:
The CTO’s Concern

Not long ago, during a client conversation, a CTO expressed a concern that resonated deeply:

“We need to extend our system. But every time someone says ‘let’s customize this,’ I feel we’re piling risk. And now with AI coming, I’m afraid our mess gets worse.”

That statement captures the heart of a challenge many SAP customers face. Customization has been both the strength and the Achilles’ heel of enterprise landscapes. It allows us to adapt, innovate, and differentiate — but it often comes with technical debt, upgrade pain, and hidden complexity.

Why Extensibility Matters More in the AI Era

Let’s pause here. Ten years ago, if you added a Z-table or tweaked a user exit, the worst-case scenario was some testing pain during an upgrade. Today?

  • If your data model is inconsistent, your AI forecasts won’t align with reality.
  • If your logic is buried in old exits, Joule copilots can’t “see” your processes.
  • If your core is brittle, cloud updates feel like risks, not opportunities.

In other words: extensibility is no longer just about “making it work.” It’s about making AI possible.

And now, with SAP’s AI ambitions accelerating — embedded copilots, Joule agents, and business data clouds powering predictive intelligence — the messy customizations of the past risk becoming blockers for the future.

This is where ABCD extensibility comes in. Far from being abstract jargon, it’s a practical compass to guide enterprises on how to extend the system smartly, safely, and in a way that enables AI instead of hindering it.

The ABCD Levels: A Human Explanation

SAP’s ABCD framework doesn’t exist to confuse us — it exists to help customers navigate the grey space between innovation and stability.

Here’s the official breakdown, with real-world translation:

A Short Story: The MV45AFZZ Debate

Anyone who has worked in SAP Sales and Distribution knows the legendary include MV45AFZZ. For decades, it’s been the go-to spot for developers to implement custom sales order checks, validations, and logic.

At one client, a senior developer proudly said, “We’ve been using MV45AFZZ for 15 years, and it works just fine. Why change?”

And he wasn’t wrong. In many ways, that’s a Level B extensibility choice: small, controlled, and serving the business well. (In fact, SAP even documented this in SAP Note 3578329, proving that not all ‘old-school’ practices are bad.)

The problem comes when dozens of such exits pile up, undocumented, with overlapping logic — and suddenly the system feels like a house of cards.

Here’s the twist: ABCD extensibility is not about banning MV45AFZZ or exits. It’s about putting them in the right place, with the right intent.

The IDoc Question: Clean or Not?

One of the most common debates I hear is: “We use IDocs everywhere. Are they clean core?”

The answer: Yes, IDocs are safe — they fall under Level B.

SAP clarified this in the IDoc Clean Core blog.

Why? Because IDocs are:

  • Officially documented.
  • Supported by SAP.
  • Used for integration and still relevant in S/4HANA.

That said, if you’re starting a greenfield cloud project, you may want to move toward APIs and Event Mesh (Level A) instead. But if you’ve got an existing landscape with IDocs, don’t panic — they’re not “unclean.”

Real-World Scenarios: Which Level to Choose?

Why This Matters for AI

AI copilots like Joule don’t “guess.” They rely on:

  • Stable APIs (Level A).
  • Clear data models (A & B).
  • Trusted logic (not buried in Level C/D).

If your system is full of Level D hacks, AI copilots won’t understand your processes. But if you steer toward A and B (with C monitored), you create an AI-ready enterprise.

 Closing Thought

Extensibility is not the villain. Misuse is.

The ABCD framework gives us a shared language:

  • A when we want innovation + AI without worry.
  • B when proven frameworks like IDocs or MV45AFZZ still serve us.
  • C only if there’s no choice — and we track it closely.
  • D only if we want to leave a headache for the next generation.

So next time someone says “let’s customize,” you don’t need to panic. You just need to ask:

Is this A, B, C, or D? And that one question can mean the difference between a system that blocks AI — and one that accelerates it.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP - Q3 2025
entry.content:
This third quarter brought some helpful innovation highlights for SAP Business Technology Platform, that we’re excited to share with you! The Q3 Innobytes demonstrate the progress we made in SAP BTP over the last months. Check out the video below and explore the latest features in Application Development, Joule and more. Enjoy watching!

 

App Dev Highlights

AI-powered Capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

In the first demo, three new AI capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone are demonstrated to help you work smarter and more efficiently.

With AI Summarization, you can create a concise summary of long documents within seconds. Simply find the content in your workspace and click Summarize to save time and work smarter.

To make engaging with content easier, you can access AI Comment Generation via the AI icon to generate contextual comments, helping respond quickly and intelligently. 

To support content creation, the AI Text Generation helps with drafting an introduction or brainstorming ideas. In the workspace editor, you can ask AI to generate Text and let it support your experience in the SAP Build Work Zone.  

Watch the demo starting at 00:09 to see these innovations in action.

Learn more

  • Blog Post SAP Build Work Zone
  • SAP Build Work Zone
  •  SAP Community

 

Skill Builder in Joule General Availability

Welcome to Joule Studio, a powerful tool that enables you to create intelligent AI agents and custom-built Joule Skills based on your specific business needs.

The creation of Joule Studio’s AI agent is seamlessly integrated with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), leveraging its robust security, scalability, and connectivity to SAP systems for maximum efficiency. In this demo, a new Joule Skill is created that automates the workflow of the badge printing process. It automatically generates and prints employee badges by integrating Joule Studio with the SAP HR database, and everything you need for this process is in one place.

Start the demo at 01:51 to get more insights.

Learn more

  • Get Started with Joule Studio
  • Detailed Tutorial
  • SAP Community Blog Page

 

Downtime-Optimized Upgrades for SAP BTP ABAP Environment

SAP BTP ABAP Environment now uses blue-green-fashioned lifecycle management to minimize the downtime during hotfixes and version upgrades.

A recent update demonstrates that switching to a new runtime takes only seconds, with release upgrades targeting about 30 minutes. This innovation aims to make the process more transparent, aligning with downtime more efficiently. With this improvement, we are minimizing downtime and optimizing upgrades! 

This demo uses an example to highlight this innovation further (starting at 03:15).

Learn more

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment – Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows in 2025

 

Integration

AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite

In August, we released an AI adapter for Cloud Integration capability of the SAP Integration Suite on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

Available as part of the Standard plan and above, it allows integration flows to interact with Large Language Models, adding AI directly into the integration at runtime. In this demo iflow, a product review is analyzed with OpenAI to enrich them with customer sentiment. This example shows the detection of a negative sentiment in a product review through GPT-5. The adapter is available now for you to try.

Watch this part (starting at 04:29) to get more insights.

Learn more

  • AI Adapter Blog Post
  • AI Adapter on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Data & Analytics

SQL Generation for SAP HANA in Joule

In SAP Build Code, Joule can now automatically generate SAP HANA SQL based on natural language prompts.

You can either execute it directly within the Joule panel or you can copy the SQL command into the SQL Console to perform additional operations or refinements. This integration streamlines workflows, boosts productivity, and reduces errors, eliminating manual coding and tool switching.

This is how it’s done:

  1. Enable SQL generation using object definitions in your workspace’s settings
  2. Navigate to your Joule extension and select the command type HANA SQL
  3. Type your Natural Language Prompt – Joule will then generate and execute the SQL for you
  4. Execute or add operations or refinements to the results

See these steps in action (starting at 05:57).

Learn more

  • Generate SQL from Natural Language using Joule

 

Cross

Modifiable Transport Requests

SAP Cloud Transport Management Service now supports Modifiable Transport Requests, allowing you to test and adjust transport requests in safe test nodes before releasing them to production.

This is how it works:

  1. Create a Modifiable Transport Request with the Create button.
  2. When opening the request, see the Tracking tab that shows the transport landscape and is now open for changes.
  3. Add content to the request and click the Test button to import directly or later and freely add or remove content.
  4. Release the request when testing is completed.

This flexible approach enables adding, removing, or redeploying content as needed, ensuring higher quality and safer deployments. Automation and Integration with other SAP BTP services are planned, so stay tuned for more to come.

To see this demo in action, watch the video (starting at 07:36).

Learn more

  • Modifiable Transport Request Blog Post

 

Cross (Cloud ALM)

Change Point Detection for Custom BTP Apps in SAP Cloud ALM

Running custom apps on SAP BTP embraces Cloud Flexibility with the Clean Core Principle. With the SAP Cloud ALM for Operations, you can monitor SAP and non-SAP applications end-to-end. This feature ensures business continuity and operational efficiency.

Real User Monitoring gives you clear insights into usage by tracking executions, performance, and response times all in one interface. 

If the performance suddenly shifts, Change Point Detection identifies unusual patterns in the performance compared to historical trends. You can then directly navigate to the respective request and even receive alerts or emails when a change point is detected. This helps quick investigation of the issue and ensures smooth operations.

This new feature is highlighted (starting at 08:52).

Learn more

  • SAP Cloud ALM for Operations Expert Portal
  • SAP BTP Developer’s Guide (Github)
  • Join us for TechEd:
  • CS101 | Discover SAP Cloud ALM for operations in action
  • CS261 | Monitoring a custom SAP BTP application with SAP Cloud ALM for operations

 

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU, and we would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Operations - Landscape
entry.content:
Dear Community,

this blog provides practical insights into setting up a proper landscape for SAP Integration Suite.

Intention:

With the move to Integration Suite as middleware, customers will reach an early point at which they need to consider their future landscape setup. SAP provides many resources (such as the Reference Architecture, Discovery Center, Naming Conventions, Learning Journey, Considerations on the System Landscape for Integration when On-boarding into SAP Cloud Integration) to help them get started and become familiar with the new environment. Based on multiple customer ramp-ups, a clear picture is emerging of what a solid setup can look like.

Approach:

We collect the basic information required to run and operate Integration Suite properly. This includes a simple consideration of the account setup and the services we recommend for your integration landscape (such as Transport Management, SAP Cloud ALM, etc.).

Solution:

How many tenants (SAP BTP subaccounts) are needed for SAP Integration Suite to support such a landscape?

"A general rule of thumb is to align the landscape of the SAP Integration Suite with the primary business system in your architecture."

However, the decision between a 2-tier or 3-tier landscape for SAP Integration Suite also depends on various organizational and functional factors:

  • A 2-tier landscape is suitable for simpler scenarios where mostly preconfigured content is used.
  • A 3-tier landscape is suitable for more complex environments with existing multi-tier on-premise systems and extended quality assurance requirements.

What about the sizing of Integration Suite in comparison to PI/PO?

As of now, the number of messages is the primary factor influencing cost. Other aspects — such as sizing — do not affect the price. Scaling is handled entirely by SAP, and there are predefined internal value sets. SAP Cloud Integration generally scales well (scale up/out), provided that the integration flows are designed according to the design guidelines.

For Edge Integration Cell, the concept is different, as the infrastructure is managed within the customer's private landscape. Therefore, planned sizing should be taken into consideration.

Are there differences between DEV, Test, and Prod regarding message calculation? What should we take into consideration?

SAP Integration Suite - Message Metric Definition serves as our source of truth for message calculation in SAP Integration Suite. It also includes the following important information: “There is no concept of development, test, and production landscapes in SAP Integration Suite. Messages on all tenants are metered based on the description in this note.”

What do we need to start with our Integration Suite setup? 

As a very basic setup, we would take the Integration Suite subscription into consideration. This means, according to question 1, we are going to deploy and roll out our landscape according to our needs. The naming of directories is flexible and can be changed afterwards. Due to this fact, in our consideration we will name the base directory Development, Test, and Production, everything else is flexibel to your customer needs. 

Architectural Overview BTP

 

General Naming - Stage Development

DirectoryDevelopment
SubaccountDev – SAP Integration Suite
Subdomaincompany-dev-sap-integration-suite-uniqueid or dev-sap-integration-suite-uniqueid
Cloud Foundry Orgdev-sap-integration-suite
Spacedev-sap-integration-suite

General Naming - Stage Test

DirectoryTest
SubaccountTest - SAP Integration Suite
Subdomaincompany-test-sap-integration-suite or test-sap-integration-suite
Cloud Foundry Orgtest-sap-integration-suite
Spacetest-sap-integration-suite

General Naming - Stage Prod

DirectoryProduction
SubaccountProd - SAP Integration Suite
Subdomaincompany-prod-sap-integration-suite-uniqueid or prod-sap-integration-suite-uniqueid
Cloud Foundry Orgprod-sap-integration-suite
Spaceprod-sap-integration-suite

Is there anything else we need to take into consideration?

Beyond the Integration Suite we recommend to take the following further Services also in consideation:

By default, you can leverage SAP's default Identity Provider (IDP) for user access and role management. Users who should work in the Integration Suite environment can be assigned predefined roles. This falls under Identity and User Management.

SAP Cloud Transport Management can be used for your basic landscape and transport scenarios in Integration Suite. Besides a file-based manual approach, you can transport your content across the landscape in a more structured way using Cloud Transport Management.

Important: If you want to leverage Cloud Transport Management in combination with Cloud ALM, the Cloud Transport Management service should not be set up within the same account as Cloud ALM. Follow the Guideline: Setup and Administration for SAP Cloud ALM.

SAP Cloud ALM helps you to implement and operate intelligent cloud and hybrid business solutions. With the Integration and Exception Monitoring for the Cloud Integration part of Integration Suite, you can already cover a comprehensive monitoring concept for your hybrid integration landscape with minimal effort. Since Cloud ALM is basically free for customers, it should be one of your key considerations.

CI/CD concept for Integration Suite.

To set up a proper CI/CD pipeline for automated transports, Integration Suite provides Management APIs, which can be leveraged in third-party solutions.

Additionally, our SAP partners offer dedicated automation tools specifically designed for Integration Suite. Check out the SAP Store to get the latest information and products, including those provided by our partners.

Besides partner solutions, there are also some open-source approaches.

Parallel development of integration flows as part of a CI/CD concept - How do we handle this? 

From a general approach, a single integration flow should be handled by one developer.

Additionally, there are many other solution approaches available, such as partner solutions (see SAP Store ) and design approaches. An individual cross-check with your implementation partner is recommended to identify the best concept for your environment.

We want to use AI features?

Check out SAP Discover Center for Integration Suite and 2903776 - SAP Integration Suite – Service Plans and Upgrade Paths with the Premium Account, AI features will be available. Take into consideration that, as of now, the Premium Service Plan is subscription-based. For more information about the connect with your SAP Account Team to find the right plan for your needs.

As of now, generative AI options are only available for specific regions. See: 3515787 - Generative AI features 

---

We’d love to hear your thoughts and experiences with SAP Integration Suite. What challenges are you facing? How can we help you unlock the full potential of your IT ecosystem? Feel free to reach out to us via SAP Integration Services.

#Modernize #Integrate #Innovate – SAP Integration Modernization TEAM

entry.title: Test Automation Solution for PO7.5 to SAP Integration Suite Migration
entry.content:
Test Automation Solution for PO 7.5 to SAP Integration Suite Migration

Enterprises are transitioning away from legacy SAP Process Orchestration (PO) towards SAP Integration Suite as PO approaches end of life. While this migration promises better scalability and integration capabilities, it also brings a significant challenge of ensuring data consistency and integrity throughout the process without disrupting business users.

In any migration project, testing can consume around 40% to 50% of the overall effort if done manually. Manual testing is time-consuming and prone to human error. Complex interfaces, multiple test cases, and large volumes of data drives up the time and cost of testing. Thoroughly validating that the new environment behaves as expected is critical to a successful transition. This is where automated testing solutions comes into play, simplifying and accelerating the validation of migrated interfaces.

 We have built a test tool to extract, compare, and validate payloads between your legacy PO system and SAP Integration Suite. This tool simplifies and automates testing of migrated iFlows, making your transition smoother, faster, and more reliable.

Key Features of Our Test Automation Tool

  • Automates payload extraction from SAP PO 7.5: Extracts input and output messages from your existing PO environment. It establishes connectivity with the PO System and pulls the payload for testing.
  • Validates test cases directly against migrated flows in Cloud Integration : Run test scenarios on the target platform(SAP Integration Suite) to verify correctness of migration.
  • Compares output payloads across systems: Detect any mismatches or errors.
  • Supports various testing approach: Whether testing single or multiple interfaces, Our tool adapts to project needs. It supports regression testing.
  • Generates detailed, downloadable test reports: Gain visibility into test results with comprehensive  reports.
  • Alerts via mails in case of failures: Immediate notifications enable quick corrective actions.
  • Supports standard adapters.
  • Monitoring through quality management and governance dashboard.

Whether you are migrating a few interfaces or hundreds, test tool brings efficiency, visibility, and reliability to your testing process saving both time and cost.

Integrating our test automation tool into your migration strategy will help with:

  • Faster testing cycles that reduce the overall migration timeline.
  • Improved reliability with consistent, repeatable automated test runs.
  • Greater visibility into testing outcomes through detailed reports.
  • Enhanced confidence that migrated interfaces behave exactly as expected.
  • Scalability to handle migrations involving just a few interfaces or hundreds.

Ready to accelerate your PO migration testing during migration? Reach out to learn how our tool can simplify your migration from PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite and save time, reduce costs, and ensure a smooth migration.

entry.title: Modernizing RFC/BAPI-based Integrations for a Clean Core with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

In most SAP landscapes, SAP Process Orchestration has long been the trusted bridge between the ERP core and the outside world — connecting SAP and non-SAP systems through RFC & BAPI calls, IDocs, and Web Services, and so on. As organizations now move toward SAP S/4HANA and SAP Integration Suite, the migration journey isn’t just about replacing middleware; it’s about evolving decades of integration logic into cloud-ready, clean-core-compliant patterns.

Among the many interface types found in SAP PI/PO, RFCs/BAPIs stand out as the most functionally embedded. They provide direct access to business objects within the SAP ERP core — for instance, to check material availability, retrieve purchase orders, or update financial postings. This tight coupling, while powerful, also poses modernization challenges, for example by not facilitating easy interoperability with external applications, in today’s composable enterprise era.

Recognizing this, SAP has expanded the Migration Assessment capability in Integration Suite to not only analyze and migrate integration artifacts, but also to recommend modernization opportunities. With the release of Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for BAPIs in Q3 2025, architects can now automatically identify BAPIs used in legacy PI/PO interfaces and discover modern, SAP-managed API equivalents via the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This opens up a structured path for customers to not just migrate their interfaces, but also modernize them for clean core and interoperability.

Note: In Q2 2025, SAP released Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for IDOCs. Now, this feature is extended to BAPIs as well.

This blog dives into what that means in practice — exploring three architectural paths for evolving BAPI-based integrations as they move from SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite, balancing speed, effort, and alignment with the clean core vision.

A word about “Clean Core” – The Guiding Principle for Continuous Transformation

Clean core is not a product — it’s a philosophy. It is a set of guiding principles that help organizations maintain an agile, upgrade-stable, and innovation-ready ERP landscape. By reducing custom code and relying on standardized, lifecycle-managed APIs and extensions, clean core supports continuous transformation without technical debt. The broader paradigm of Clean core, can be approached in 5 different dimensions, with Integration being one of them, as mentioned in the following figure:

Learn more about the Clean Core approach

Three Architectural Paths to Move BAPI-Based Integrations to SAP Integration Suite

When moving your legacy RFC/BAPI-based interfaces from SAP PO to Integration Suite, there are multiple approaches — each balancing speed, effort, and modernization depth.

Let’s look at these three paths:

Approach

Lift and Shift

Clean Core Modernization

Protocol Modernization

What it entails

Continue to use the RFCs/BAPIs as-is and connect them directly from Integration Suite using the RFC adapter.

Replace BAPIs with standard APIs published by SAP, documented in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Replace the RFC connectivity by exposing the same RFC/BAPI as a SOAP Web Service.

Benefits / drawbacks

⇧ Fastest transition with minimal rework

⇧ No revalidation of business logic or functional behaviour

⇩ No interoperability. Opportunity to modernise is not leveraged.

⇧ These APIs are SAP-managed, upgrade-stable, and designed for HANA-optimized data access.

⇧ Facilitates interoperability.

⇩ SOA Manager Z-objects are customer-managed.

Key enablers

Migration Tooling (automated flow conversion from PO ICO to Cloud Integration iflow)

⟹ Migration Assessment → Modernization Recommendations

⟹ Explore APIs on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Kindly refer following tutorial / blog links:

⟹  How easy it is to consume a Function Module as a Web Service

⟹  Modernize RFC Receiver Connectivity

Best suited for

⟹ Interim phases where backend refactoring is not yet possible (e.g., ECC system, not yet on S/4HANA)

⟹ Projects under strict time constraints where migration speed takes priority

Building a future-ready, interoperable, and clean-core-compliant integration landscape

⟹ Scenarios where no equivalent SAP standard API exists.

⟹ Transitional architectures that need interoperability before full modernization.

Tips & considerations

The best time to start your PO modernization was yesterday — the next best is today. Early planning prevents “lift and shift” compulsions later on.

⟹ Requires functional remapping between legacy BAPI fields and API structure

⟹ Regression testing and business validation needed

 

Now, we will showcase how a BAPI based interface in our SAP PO landscape can be moved to Integration Suite, applying 1) Lift and Shift, and 2) Clean Core modernization approaches (We will not be covering the Protocol Modernization approach in this post, as it is already nicely covered in the blog / tutorials written by my colleagues – links to which I have shared in the above table).

Example BAPI-based Interface setup in SAP PO:

Consider the example of Material ATP check interface, which uses BAPI_MATERIAL_AVAILABILITY, to fetch the available stock quantity of a given Material, at a given Plant and Storage location. The BAPI is exposed to consuming application SAP CPQ, via a REST API layer, in our SAP PO system. Following are a few screenshots of the interface setup in PO system, specifically also highlighting the request and response fields.

Migration using Lift and Shift approach:

Here, we illustrate how this interface can be moved to Cloud Integration, using Lift and Shift approach, with the aid of Migration Tooling. As we mentioned in the above table, this approach will retain the RFC adapter as it is, in the automatically generated Cloud Integration iflow artifact.

Note: There are additional pre-requisite steps to connect your PO system to BTP sub-account, through the Cloud connector. Kindly refer this help portal page, for more details. This is an essential step, to be able to do Migration Assessment as well as to migrate interfaces from PO to Cloud Integration, using Migration Tooling.

We launch the Migration Tooling guided wizard, by clicking the Migrate button, from within the package.

At the end of the guided wizard, we see that the integration flow is automatically generated, keeping the technical implementation aspects, exactly as it was in PO system (such as connectivity protocols, message mappings, message schema, etc.)

The iflow is broken into multiple integration processes, for better readability. In this case, the request and response mapping steps are modularised into separate integration processes, which are called from the main integration process.

 

The following screenshot shows a closer view of the main integration process – with receiver adapter RFC being used to call S/4HANA system, to fetch the Material ATP information.

Migration using Clean Core Modernization approach:

Next, we will walk you through the Clean core modernization approach, to move our BAPI_MATERIAL_AVAILABILITY based interface to Cloud Integration.

As stated in the beginning of this post, we start with analysing the latest generated Migration Assessment report. If you have run the migration assessment of your PO landscape before SAP released the “Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for BAPIs” feature, kindly re-run the assessment. The new version of the report will have additional worksheets, containing these recommendations.

In the Recommendations sheet, you can see the Possible Modernization Item across each pillar – such as Protocol, Security, Clean core, Integration Style, etc.

In the API Recommendations sheet, you can see the equivalent S/4HANA API for the underlying BAPIs used in each of the PO interfaces, that uses BAPI based integration.

Next, we proceed to Business Accelerator hub, to explore the API definition of the recommended API:

This OData API can be adopted in our Cloud Integration iflow or be exposed to other applications via API Management layer, to fetch the Material ATP details. We leave the implementation details to you, to model the orchestration layer, as you deem fit, based on your business scenario.

With this approach, we have modernized a BAPI based integration into a modern one – i.e. OData API based, thereby reaping the benefits such as upgrade-stable interface, clean core, interoperability, and so on.

Closing Thoughts

Integration modernization is not just a migration exercise — it’s an opportunity to realign enterprise integration with the clean core vision and build a foundation for continuous transformation & business agility, by taking advantage of the modern, cloud-native features and open protocols offered by SAP Integration Suite.
Every interface we modernize is a building block of a cleaner, more interoperable ERP core. With SAP Integration Suite and the new modernization recommendations, the journey from legacy BAPIs to standard APIs has never been clearer — or more achievable.

entry.title: A importância de utilizar o Trace em iFlows com OData
entry.content:
O uso do Trace nos iFlows é uma prática essencial para garantir visibilidade, controle e eficiência nas integrações que utilizam OData Services. Em cenários de integração com sistemas como o SAP Business One, S/4HANA ou SuccessFactors, o OData é frequentemente usado para consultas, inserções e atualizações de dados — operações que exigem precisão e monitoramento detalhado.

Por que o Trace é importante

 

  1. Diagnóstico detalhado de erros O Trace permite visualizar o conteúdo completo das mensagens em cada etapa do iFlow. Isso é fundamental para identificar falhas na comunicação OData, como:
  2. Transparência nas transformações de dados Durante o processamento, o iFlow pode aplicar várias transformações — como Content Modifier, Message Mapping e Groovy Scripts. O Trace mostra como cada etapa altera o payload, permitindo validar se os dados enviados ao endpoint OData estão corretos.
  3. Redução do tempo de troubleshooting Sem o Trace, identificar a origem de um problema pode exigir múltiplas execuções e logs incompletos. Com o Trace ativo, é possível analisar o fluxo completo de uma única execução e resolver o problema com agilidade.
  4. Auditoria e rastreabilidade O Trace oferece um histórico técnico de como as mensagens foram processadas. Isso é especialmente importante em ambientes corporativos com exigências de auditoria, conformidade ou qualidade de dados.
  5. Validação de performance e payloads grandes Ao testar integrações OData que envolvem grandes volumes de dados ou múltiplas entidades, o Trace ajuda a entender gargalos e o comportamento do sistema sob carga.

 

Boas práticas ao usar o Trace

 

  • Ativar o Trace apenas durante testes e diagnósticos  não em produção por longos períodos, pois ele consome mais recursos.
  • Sempre analisar o payload antes e depois de chamadas OData, para confirmar que o formato e os dados estão corretos.
  • Documentar os principais cenários encontrados nos Traces para uso futuro da equipe.

 

 

XML do Odata que foi convertido para Json

 

IFlow Completo

 

O objetivo do iFlow é fazer uma chamada OData, converter e ajustar a resposta, e então finalizar o processo possivelmente enviando os dados para outro sistema ou armazenando para uso posterior.

Fluxo geral: Início → Montagem da requisição → Chamada OData → Conversão e tratamento → Fim

🔹 1. Início do iFlow

Este é o trigger (ponto de entrada). Pode ser acionado manualmente, por evento ou por outro sistema. Ele inicia o processo de integração.

🔹 2. “Creat Body” (Content Modifier)

Responsável por criar o corpo (payload) da requisição OData. Aqui normalmente se define um JSON ou XML com os dados que serão enviados ao endpoint OData.

👉 Exemplo:

{
  "CardCode": "C0001",
  "CardName": "Cliente Exemplo"
}

Se o iFlow faz uma operação POST ou PATCH, este bloco é essencial para montar o corpo da mensagem.

🔹 3. “Create Header” (Content Modifier)

Define os headers HTTP necessários para a chamada OData. Por exemplo:

 

  • Content-Type: application/json
  • Accept: application/json
  • Authorization: Basic … (se estiver usando autenticação básica)

 

Esses cabeçalhos garantem que o serviço OData entenda corretamente a requisição.

🔹 4. “Request Reply 1”

Este componente faz a chamada ao serviço OData. É onde o CPI realmente se comunica com o destino configurado (no caso, o componente “OData” mostrado abaixo). Ele envia o payload criado anteriormente e aguarda uma resposta.

👉 Este é o ponto mais crítico do iFlow — onde é importante usar o modo Trace para inspecionar a requisição e a resposta, validando o que foi enviado e recebido.

🔹 5. “OData” (Receiver Channel)

É o endpoint configurado no Adapter OData. Ele define:

 

  • A URL do serviço 
  • O método (GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE)
  • As credenciais de autenticação
  • Eventuais parâmetros adicionais

 

Aqui é onde o iFlow realmente “fala” com o sistema SAP ou outro sistema OData.

🔹 6. “XML to JSON Converter 1”

Converte a resposta do OData (que normalmente vem em XML) para JSON, formato mais fácil de manipular em scripts ou para enviar a outras APIs.

🔹 7. “SET JSON” (Content Modifier)

Aqui o iFlow provavelmente ajusta o JSON resultante — adicionando campos, renomeando chaves ou preparando o payload final para o próximo passo. Pode ser usado para garantir consistência de estrutura antes de enviar ao destino final.

🔹 8. “Groovy Script 1”

Etapa de tratamento customizado. Aqui é possível:

 

  • Fazer validações de negócio
  • Extrair campos específicos do JSON
  • Montar logs
  • Fazer cálculos ou formatações adicionais

 

Um exemplo comum seria:

def body = message.getBody(String)
def json = new groovy.json.JsonSlurper().parseText(body)
json.totalClientes = json.value.size()
message.setBody(new groovy.json.JsonBuilder(json).toPrettyString())
return message

🔹 9. “End 1”

Finaliza o fluxo. Pode apenas encerrar o processo ou enviar os dados tratados para outro sistema (ex: API REST, fila, e-mail, etc.).

entry.title: Streamlining Data with SAP CPI Message Mapping : Sorting and Eliminating Incomplete Records
entry.content:
Introduction

In enterprise integration scenarios, managing employee data across systems is a common requirement — but raw data is often messy or incomplete.

In this blog, we’ll walk through a real-world solution in SAP Integration Suite (CPI) where we:
• Filter out invalid employee records using Message Mapping
• Sort valid employee records by EmployeeID using Groovy Script
• Deliver a clean and structured employee dataset to the target system

The goal is to streamline incoming employee data so it’s ready for consumption by downstream applications.

Business Requirement
We needed to:
• ✅ Remove employees missing EmployeeID
• ✅ Preserve only complete records with all required fields
• ✅ Sort the remaining employee records in ascending order by EmployeeID

This reflects a common need in systems like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP HCM, or third-party HR tools where employee records must be clean and ordered.

Note: 
The entire filtering and sorting of employee data could be handled using just a Groovy script. However, here I chose to use Message Mapping for filtering and Groovy only for sorting.
This approach helps demonstrate how standard tools in SAP CPI can be combined effectively — and it’s especially helpful for beginners learning both graphical and scripting options.

⚙️Tools Used
• SAP Integration Suite (CPI)
• Message Mapping – to filter out incomplete data
• Groovy Script – to sort valid data
• No external tools, APIs, or adapters needed

Better Picture

Steps to follow

  • Step 1: Filter Incomplete Records Using Message Mapping. In CPI, we first create a Message Mapping between the source and target structures (Employees → Employees).
    Goal: remove any <Employee> node where EmployeeID is missing or empty.

    Functions Used:
    • removeContext : Flattens or isolates repeated elements from their surrounding hierarchy, treating each entry as a separate context so that they can be processed individually
    • Length: return the number of characters in the given string (used here to check if EmployeeID is empty or not).
    • GreaterThan: compares two numbers and returns true if the first is greater than the second.
    • constant: provides a fixed value to compare against.
    • createIf: creates the corresponding target node only if the connected Boolean condition is true.



    EmployeeID(on source side) is mapped to Employee(on target side) to only pass records having non-empty EmployeeID.
    This is known as conditional node creation.
    Below is the mapping expression used to conditionally create nodes having non-empty EmployeeID.



    We map the rest of the fields directly one to one like shown below.




  • Step 2: Sort Valid Records Using Groovy Script

    Important Tip: Why We Use Groovy for Sorting
    🚫Message Mapping in SAP CPI cannot perform sorting operations.
    ✅It is designed for mapping and filtering data, but not for ordering or rearranging nodes.

    That’s why sorting must be handled by a Groovy script (or other scripting steps like XSLT) if required.
    If your source system can sort data (e.g., an OData service or database), it’s best to sort at the source when possible.
    But when that’s not feasible, a post-mapping script like the one we used is the recommended approach.

    With just two steps we’ve transformed raw employee data into a clean, filtered, and sorted dataset ready for use.

    This approach can be applied to:
    • HR integrations
    • Payroll systems
    • Internal reporting systems
    • Master data consolidation flows

entry.title: Handling Large-Scale Data Loads in SAP Cloud Integration using Snowflake Adapter
entry.content:
Integration scenarios require frequent data communication and exchange between different applications and environments. Cloud data platforms such as Snowflake provide efficient data storage and analytics. Snowflake Adapter for SAP Integration Suite is a great tool to solve your integration problems while offering a reliable and scalable capability for data-related integrations.

Snowflake Adapter in SAP CI

Snowflake Adapters can be used to implement various data solutions, a few of them are as follows:

  • Transaction Analysis for retail business : Seamlessly load high-volume transactional data into Snowflake to analyze buying behavior, sales trends, and inventory performance enabling smarter business decisions.
  • Data Archival & Historical Analysis : Adapter can be used Move large datasets into Snowflake for secure storage and long-term trend analysis without impacting operational systems.

  • Supply Chain Data : Integrate logistics, ERP, and vendor data into Snowflake to monitor supply chain efficiency.

With this, in the following sections, we will explore the key functionalities and features of the adapter in detail.

Overview

The Snowflake adapter is designed to be employed as a receiver adapter. In such a scenario, SAP Cloud Integration acts as the initiator of the calls. The adapter uses database authentication and JDBC as the transport protocol.

You can perform various CRUD operations on your Snowflake application and choose from a list of different staging storage options, such as Amazon S3, Google Cloud Storage, and Microsoft Azure.  

Below is the high-level overview of how the adapter interacting with Snowflake Application and SAP Cloud Integration.

 

Key Features

The Snowflake Adapter provides the following key features:

  • Bulk Export and Import: Supports reading files from multiple input formats like CSV, JSON, and Avro. Export data to your desired format using unload operation.
  • Snowflake Operations Support: Snowflake Adapter offers support for standard Snowflake operations (CRUD Operations).
  • Multiple options for Staging Storage: Snowflake Adapter provides various options to load data into staging storage like Amazon S3, Google Cloud Storage, or Microsoft Azure.
  • Secure Authentication: Provides secure authentication with Database Account and
    Key-Pair options.


Snowflake Adapter Integration: Practical Use Case Walkthrough:

Imagine a business scenario where 1 million records from an ERP system need to be loaded into Snowflake. If we take the straightforward route of simply fetching the data from ERP and pushing it into Snowflake, the process could drag on for several minutes. But what if we could speed things up dramatically?

By smartly combining a set of Integration Suite palettes with the Snowflake adapter, I have built a custom batch processing mechanism with which, the same operation can be completed in just a matter of seconds—delivering both speed and efficiency.

In this blog, I’ll Walk you through how to handle such high-volume data insertion with the Snowflake adapter, and we’ll also take a look at how the execution unfolds inside Snowflake itself.

Before we begin, let us assume that a table is available in Snowflake with the required schema.

CI iflow Design

Mapping Component:

Once the data is received in SAP Integration Suite; the payload will be mapped to required column headers, which are defined in the target table in Snowflake. We employ an iterating splitter to split the records into groups (defined in the Grouping field) and then insert the records in Snowflake. 

Splitter Component:

Using the Iterating Splitter, you can enable the Streaming checkbox to improve efficiency by splitting a large composite message into smaller chunks for processing. Additionally, you can enable Parallel Processing of split messages to enhance efficiency. You can specify this by providing value for Number of Concurrent Processes.

Note: You can modify the grouping, utilize parallel processing and adjust the number of concurrent processes based on your requirements.

XML Modifier Component:

XML Modifier is used to remove the XML declaration from the XML body to make XML compatible with the snowflake.



Content Modifier Component - Payload for Snowflake Adapter Insert Operation:

Content Modifier is used to store the payload to be inserted in the table. The following instructions are handy while creating the body for the payload. 

  1. Specify the table structure including datatype and columns in the <metadata> tag. 
  2. Use the <row> tag for values to be inserted. Below is the sample XML Payload for the Insert operation:
<root> 
	<metadata> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>CREATION_DATETIME</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>RECORDTYPE</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>DOC_NO</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>ITEM</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>CREATED_ON</fieldname>	 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>REF_ITEM</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = “VARCHAR”>CREATED_BY</fieldname> 
	<metadata> 
	<row> 
		<CREATION_DATETIME>23012025</CREATION_DATETIME> 
		<RECORDTYPE>010101</RECORDTYPE> 
		<DOC_NO>2020202</DOC_NO> 
		<ITEM>12345</ITEM> 
		<CREATED_ON>01012025</CREATED_ON> 
		<REF_ITEM>011</REF_ITEM> 
		<CREATED_BY>AUSR</CREATED_BY> 
	</row> 
</root>

Note: metadata/row tags and datatype attributes are case-sensitive and must be in lowercase. 

Insert Using Snowflake Adapter

Switch to the Processing tab to perform the Insert.

Now the iflow designing and configuration is complete, the iflow is ready to accept the data.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Demo:

Data has been triggered from ERP and data has been inserted into snowflake.


Navigate Monitoring, you can observe that the records are inserted in Snowflake.

You can verify the same by logging into the Snowflake application. In the Monitoring section, SQL queries are created for individual records.

Earlier using a direct insertion approach, the data load into Snowflake typically required approximately 10–12 minutes. By implementing the optimized iflow design outlined above, the same volume of records is processed and inserted into the Snowflake application within 30–35 seconds, demonstrating a significant improvement in performance and efficiency.

Final Thoughts

In summary, the Snowflake adapter enables smooth, secure, and scalable integration between cloud applications and Snowflake. The successful insertion of records highlights its efficiency and reliability, positioning it as a key enabler for enterprises looking to modernize their data landscape and leverage Snowflake’s analytics capabilities.

References: https://api.sap.com/package/SnowflakeAdapterforSAPIntegrationSuite/overview

Note: The Snowflake adapter is available as part of your SAP Integration Suite license.

entry.title: What's new in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model – September 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

I’m happy to announce that the September release of SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) is available. It’s packed with many great new features! This blog post highlights some of the new features. It presents a range of exciting new capabilities, such as the new MCP servers or the integration with Application Frontend service. In addition, we collected some informative blog posts delving into various aspects of CAP and give you an overview on upcoming events.

Check out the details of what's new!

 

Enabling Agentic Development with MCP Servers

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard that bridges the gap between large language models (LLMs) and external resources such as services, tools, data, and workflows, so models can fetch context, take actions, and deliver more accurate results. MCP is already supported by clients such as Claude, Cline, Cursor, and VS Code.

Beginning of September, SAP introduced MCP servers for CAP, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5. These MCP servers are designed specifically for building enterprise-grade SAP business applications taking into account proven best practices and providing recommendations tailored to SAP Business Technology Platform.

Welcome to cap-js/mcp-server

For further information, I highly recommend you to read this blog post: SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers to enable agentic development for Enterprise Applications.

 

Easily Integrate with Application Frontend Service

The Application Frontend service is a SaaS application on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), which serves as a single entry point for hosting, serving and operating frontend applications. It is part of SAP Build, SAP’s unified solution for application development and process automation. By consolidating all aspects of UI application management under one managed service, Application Frontend service simplifies the development experience and enhances custom application operations. For an introduction to Application Frontend service, please read this blog post.

With our latest CAP release it is now possible to easily integrate the Application Frontend service. All you have to do is use the command cds add app-frontend. This adds all the needed configuration to your project providing you access to Application Frontend’s cool features. No additional work for you to do!

Please note: The support for this service is currently limited to single-tenant applications.

 

Integration with SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh now Generally Available

SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh enables real-time, asynchronous communication. It works across hybrid, multi-cloud, and edge environments. The advanced event mesh integrates SAP and non-SAP systems into your event-driven architecture and allows you to form meshes of event brokers. You can publish and subscribe to business events from all kinds of SAP and non-SAP event sources. As a result, event-driven architecture and advanced event mesh keep systems and users up to date when critical changes occur. Advanced event mesh allows to manage, monitor, and visualize decentralized event streaming across your landscape.

In May, we released the beta version of our integration with advanced event mesh. After a successful test and evaluation phase, we are now happy to tell you that both open-source plugins (for Node.js and for Java) are now generally available (GA). The GA release comes with a notable addition: the support for cross-subaccount broker validation, allowing you to share advanced event mesh instances between multiple subaccounts.

Additional details can be found here.

 

Translated Error Messages in CAP Node.js

For a better user experience, error messages that appear on the UI should be translated into the same language as the rest of their application. Therefore, CAP Node.js delivers translations for annotation-based input validations out of the box in all CAP-supported languages. For a list of the messages that are currently translated, see the documentation.

Screenshot: Translation of error codes to German language

To learn more about error handling in Node.js, please read the following section in the documentation. For additional information about internationalization in Node.js, check out this section.

For those of you, who use CAP Java: translated error messages are also supported there. Please look at the documentation, to gain further insights.

 

Further Readings & Events

Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP

Using CSV files to load initial data or sample data is convenient but you must be careful when deploying data to SAP S/4HANA Cloud as you might risk losing data. In his blog post Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP, SAP Champion Mio Yasutake explains alternative approaches how to avoid data loss.

 

Providing Feedback on CAP Documentation

Your feedback is crucial for us to improve. Thus, we would like to ask you to share your feedback on our CAP documentation. There are many ways to provide us your feedback. In his blog post Multiple Ways to Give Feedback on CAP Documentation, my colleague Rene guides you through the different options.

 

SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Customer Roundtable

The next CAP Customer Roundtable is just around the corner. If you are interested in an overview of the recent features, demos, presentations and questions raised by the CAP community, mark your calendar for October 15th, 2025, 11 AM EST | 5 PM CE(S)T. Find further details (including the agenda and dial in data) in this blog post.

 

Devtoberfest 2025

Devtoberfest 2025 already started. In 2025, the event is taking place from September 29th until October 24th. But you can still consume the content. Devtoberfest is a virtual event giving SAP developers a great opportunity to get ready for SAP TechEd. It is packed with enablement sessions around topics in the area of CAP, ABAP, Tooling and Frontend, Integration, Data and AI, combined with a lot of fun. For further information, read the Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome! blog post and join the Devtoberfest group in SAP Community to take part in this great event!

 

SAP TechEd 2025

From November 4–6, 2025 SAP TechEd takes place providing you the opportunity to learn about the latest innovations and advancements in SAP technologies and to connect with the community. In 2025, SAP TechEd will be a hybrid event combining the best of both worlds: the in-person event in Berlin and the virtual event. Both events are taking place in parallel. Make sure to save the date and register now for Berlin or virtual!

The session catalogs for the in-person and the virtual event are now live, featuring a wide range of topics across various tracks, where you'll find many sessions on the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model.

 

For further information on new features, please have a look at the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Release Notes. If you want to stay up-to-date with news, learning resources, and product and strategy updates for CAP: follow our tag in the SAP Community.

We look forward to seeing how you use these new capabilities to create innovative solutions and drive your projects forward. Stay tuned for more updates and happy coding! 😊

entry.title: Integration Advisor: Early UN/EDIFACT Versions with Syntax Version 2 Now Available
entry.content:
Today, I would like to share an update regarding the B2B Library versions included in our Integration Advisor (of SAP Integration Suite) offering. Recently, we added three additional UN/EDIFACT versions from the early 1990s. 

Early Versions of the UN/EDIFACT standard

We have added three additional early versions: 90.2 S2, 91.1 S2 and 91.2 S2 – bringing the total number of supported UN/EDIFACT versions to 63.

To the best of our knowledge, even older versions (particularly 90.1 S1) are not in productive use. However, please contact us if you require this S1 version, and we will evaluate whether it can be added.

Interoperability of Syntax Version 2 (S2) and Syntax Version 3 (S3)

UN/EDIFACT syntax versions (defined by ISO 9735) are sets of rules specifying the structure of EDIFACT messages. To date, four syntax versions have been published by the UN/ECE organization: S1, S2, S3, and S4.  

These syntax versions are, in a way, orthogonal to the UN/EDIFACT versions / releases (such as 91.2 or D.01B). However, it is common practice to display UN/EDIFACT versions alongside the syntax version that was in use at the time the UN/EDIFACT version was published (e.g., 91.2 S2 or D.01B S3).

Accordingly, Integration Advisor displays all previously published UN/EDIFACT versions with the suffix S3, while the recently added versions are shown with the suffix S2.

It is important to note that syntax versions 2 and 3 are almost identical, differing only in the allowed code pages (UNOA-UNOB for S2 versus UNOA-UNOF for S3) defined in data element UNB > S001 > 0001.

This is why you can also use later UN/EDIFACT versions with syntax version 2 or use earlier UN/EDIFACT versions with syntax version 3.  

Code Values for syntax-related Data Elements  

The UN/EDIFACT standard includes certain core data elements, typically named 00**, which are used in service segments such as UNB, UNG, UNH, UNT, or UNZ. Originally, the UN/ECE organization did not provide code values for some of these core data elements and only began doing so in the mid-1990s.

Integration Advisor strives to publish B2B Library definitions as provided by the standardization organizations. As a result, the recently added UN/EDIFACT versions do not include code values for data elements 0002, 0052, or 0054.

Handling of Code Values associated with UN/CEFACT codelists

Since 1991, UN/ECE has recommended using UN/CEFACT codelists for certain UN/EDIFACT data elements. The table below lists the affected data elements along with their assigned UN/CEFACT codelists: 

Data ElementDescriptionUN/EDIFACT CodelistUN/CEFACT Codelist
4053Delivery or transport terms4053Rec 5
4277Payment terms4277Rec 17
4405Transport status4405Rec 24
6411Measurement units6411Rec 20 
7065Package types7065Rec 21
8023Freight and charges identification8023Rec 23
8067Transport modes8067Rec 19
8179Transport means8179Rec 28

Accordingly, Integration Advisor provides links from these data elements to the latest version of the listed UN/CEFACT recommendations. This applies to all versions of UN/EDIFACT starting from 91.1 S2. (Please note that the UN/EDIFACT standard did not maintain any code values for these data elements in the earlier version 90.2 S2.)

For versions 91.1 S2 and 91.2 S2, we also provide UN/EDIFACT codelists containing the code values as they were originally published by the UN/EDIFACT standard. In your Message Implementation Guideline (MIG), you have the option to use either the original UN/EDIFACT code values or the current UN/CEFACT code values.  

Consumption in Cloud Integration  

Since earlier this year, the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite has supported all UN/EDIFACT syntax versions (S1 through S4). This means you can process UN/EDIFACT payloads in all the EDI flow steps, such as EDI Splitter, EDI Extractor, EDI-To-XML Converter, and XML-To-EDI Converter, based on all these syntax versions. 

Note: You need to use the latest version of these EDI flow steps. In your Integration Flow, simply add the EDI flow steps from the palette to ensure you are using the newest version.

For the older UN/EDIFACT versions, there is one additional detail to note: 

  • Since release D.93A S3 in 1993, UN/EDIFACT has used the value D for field UNH > S009 > 0052. As a result, the EDI flow steps expect an XSD file name like UN-EDIFACT_ORDERS_D96A.xsd.
  • However, for releases prior to D.93A S3, other values (such as 1 or 2) were used for field UNH > S009 > 0052. In these cases, the EDI flow steps expect an XSD file name like UN-EDIFACT_ORDERS_2912.xsd.

Integration Advisor has recently added a new field Configure EDIFACT Message Version to tab Runtime Context (of your MIG) where this value can be maintained - see the screenshot below.   

When you create a new Message Implementation Guideline (MIG), Integration Advisor automatically selects an appropriate default value based on the following rules: 

  • Use D as the default value for all UN/EDIFACT versions starting with D (from D.93A onwards) 
  • Use 1 as the default value for all UN/EDIFACT versions not starting with D and having a minor version of 1 (applies to versions 91.1 S2 and 92.1 S3) 
  • Use 2 as the default value for all UN/EDIFACT versions not starting with D and having a minor version of 2 (applies to versions 90.2 S2, 91.2 S2, and 93.2 S3) 

In most cases, the default value should meet your requirements. If not, you can easily redefine this value in your MIG.

Conclusion

With this latest update, Integration Advisor has added three early UN/EDIFACT versions associated with Syntax Version 2. This enables you to build your Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs) and Mapping Guidelines (MAGs) based on these S2 versions.

entry.title: Designing Scalable Integration Flows in SAP BTP Using Pallets and Adapters
entry.content:
Introduction 

 SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) offers powerful tools through the SAP Integration Suite to design, deploy, and manage integration flows. However, as systems grow, so does the complexity of integrations. This blog explores how pallets and adapters can be leveraged to build scalable, modular, and maintainable integration flows in SAP BTP. 

Why Scalability Matters in Integration Design 

Scalable integration flows are essential for: 

  • Handling increasing data volumes. 
  • Supporting multiple systems and protocols. 
  • Reducing maintenance overhead. 
  • Improving performance and reliability. 

 

What Are Pallets? 

Pallets are reusable integration components that encapsulate common logic. Think of them as building blocks that can be reused across multiple integration flows. 

 

 

  1. Logging Pallet 

             Purpose: Captures and stores transaction details for auditing and debugging.

           Contents: 

  • Content Modifier: Extracts headers and payload metadata. 
  • Script Step (Groovy): Formats log message. 
  • Write to Data Store or external logging system. 
  1. Transformation Pallet  

           Purpose: Applies business rules and transforms data formats. Contents: 

  • Message Mapping: Converts data formats (e.g., JSON to XML). 

 

 

  • Script Step (Groovy): Applies custom business logic. 
  • Content Modifier: Adds or modifies fields. 
  1. Error Handling Pallet 

               Purpose: Manages exceptions and ensures graceful failure handling. Contents: 

  • Exception Subprocess: Captures errors. 
  • Script Step: Extracts error details. 
  • Email or Webhook Adapter: Sends alerts. 
  • Logging Step: Records error context. 
  1. Notification Pallet  

           Purpose: Sends alerts or notifications based on business events. Contents: 

  • Content Modifier: Prepares notification message. 
  • Mail Adapter or Webhook Adapter: Sends notification. 

 

 

  • Router: Determines notification conditions. 
  1. Security Pallet  

          Purpose: Applies security checks or token validation. Contents: 

  • Script Step: Validates JWT or API keys. 
  • Content Modifier: Extracts security headers. 
  • Router: Enforces access control. 

 

You can create a pallet as a separate integration flow and invoke it using the Process Direct adapter, enabling loose coupling and reusability. 

What Are Adapters? 

Adapters are connectors that enable communication between SAP Integration Suite and external systems. They abstract the complexity of protocols and data formats, allowing developers to focus on business logic. 

  1. REST Adapter  

Purpose: Communicates with RESTful APIs.  

Features: Supports GET, POST, PUT, DELETE; handles JSON/XML; supports OAuth2, Basic Auth. 

  1. SOAP Adapter  

Purpose: Communicates with legacy SOAP-based web services. 

 Features: Supports WSDL; handles XML/SOAP envelopes; supports WS-Security.

 

 

  1. OData Adapter  

Purpose: Interacts with SAP systems like S/4HANA using OData protocol.  

Features: Supports CRUD operations; handles JSON/XML; supports OAuth2/SAML. 

  1. IDoc Adapter 

 Purpose: Sends or receives IDocs from SAP ERP systems. 

 Features: Supports ALE/EDI; handles structured IDoc formats; requires SAP connectivity. 

  1. JDBC Adapter  

Purpose: Connects to relational databases.  

Features: Executes SQL queries; supports Oracle, SQL Server, HANA; requires JDBC driver. 

  1. ProcessDirect Adapter  

Purpose: Enables internal communication between integration flows.  

Features: Lightweight; no network overhead; ideal for calling pallets. 

  1. SFTP Adapter  

Purpose: Transfers files over secure FTP.  

Features: Supports file polling, reading, writing; handles encryption and authentication. 

 

 

 

 Each adapter supports configuration options for authentication, headers, payload formats, and error handling. 

 

 

 

Conclusion 

Designing scalable integration flows in SAP BTP is not just about connecting systems — it’s about building a robust, future-proof architecture. By leveraging pallets and adapters, you can create modular, maintainable, and high-performing integration solutions that grow with your business. 

Let’s Connect! 

Have questions or feedback? Drop a comment below or connect with me on SAP Community. I’d love to hear how you’re using pallets and adapters in your integration projects!

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite: What’s New in Q3/2025
entry.content:
Another quarter has come to an end and it’s time for us to review the most recent updates and improvements delivered to SAP Integration Suite. Whether you’re an integration architect, developer, or business leader, these new features are designed to help you get the most out of your hybrid landscape. Read on to discover what’s new and how these enhancements can support your organisation’s integration goals.

Message status overview monitoring for large tenants

One awaited featured has been released to the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite to improve Message Status Overview monitoring and support larger time intervals through data preaggregation. Now the monitoring option can be utilized for extended periods on tenants with a high volume of message processing logs.

Artificial Intelligence

AI-based integration flow generation with mediation steps

Earlier this year, the generation of integration flows with the assistance of AI was made available to customers. This enable users to generate an integration flow with sender and receiver systems based on a scenario description provided in natural language. You can read more about it here.

In Q3/2025 we have enhanced this feature to include additional mediation steps. This means that now, users can provide even more detailed scenarios and the tool identifies the details and generates a comprehensive integration flow with the described components, systems, and actions. Get a first glimpse into how to use this feature in the blog post: SAP Integration Suite – Generative AI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediation Steps.

 Business Accelerators

Joule copilot-based conversational search and discovery of content

Joule has arrived at the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in Q3 to help users find the right content throughconversational context-based search. The Joule-based discovery provides user guidance to search different artifacts and access cohesive information for other relevant sources, such as help documentation.

Note: The feature is currently in the beta phase and you can find more details on availability here.  

Connectivity and Adapters

The latest releases of SAP Integration Suite introduced a new array of adapters and connectors designed to streamline and enhance connectivity, improve data flow, and foster a more integrated digital landscape for businesses leveraging SAP solutions.

AI adapter

The recently released AI adapter for SAP Integration Suite functions as a receiver adapter and accelerates connectivity to the Generative AI Hub (SAP AI Core) and other AI providers, as needed by customer (BYOM).

 The benefit of this adapter is that it increases connectivity options to integrate with both SAP and third-party systems and applications. How it works: after configuration, data exchange is performed at runtime where the SAP Integration Suite tenant sends the operation request to GenAIHub. The AI Adapter works on the request and sends the data back to the SAP Integration Suite tenant.

Find the AI Adapter at SAP Business Accelerator Hub, read the help documentation, and check out the short demo below:

Further adapters released in Q3 include:

IBM MQ adapter using JMS protocol: client certificate supportSupports Client Certificate based authentication for JMS Variants. A new version 1.3.0 of the IBM MQ adapter supports Client Certificate based authentication for JMS Variants.- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter
IBM MQ adapter using JMS protocol: client certificate supportSupports On-Premise Connectivity via Cloud Connector for JMS Variants. A new version 1.4.0 of the IBM MQ adapter supports On-Premise Connectivity via Cloud Connector for JMS Variants.

- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Sender Adapter

- Configure the IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter
BigCommerce adapterFacilitates the connectivity to BigCommerce GraphQL & REST Admin APIs, accelerates the implementation time and reduces complexity of connecting to BigCommerce. This adapter is available on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

- BigCommerce Adapter at SAP Business Accelerator Hub

- BigCommerce Receiver Adapter

🚀🚀Discover the latest content packages, including APIs and Integrations, released on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub by our partners in Q3 2025. These releases come with high-level details to help you understand their features and benefits.

API-Centric & Event-Driven Integrations

Support for reusable API artifacts in Edge Integration Cell

Customers can now leverage components, endpoints, and services across multiple applications, projects, or contexts, without having to perform significant adaptations. The reusability of API artifacts enables companies to implement a centralized security and traffic management system for exposed APIs. It not only enhances compliance and reduces misconfiguration risks but also significantly lowers both the total cost of development and ownership by eliminating redundant configurations and promoting the reuse of existing API artifacts, which means additional API calls are avoided, leading to cost savings. Learn more.

 

Watch the demo from this year's Devtoberfest - Session "Next generation hybrid integration with Edge Integration Cell":

Integration of Advanced Event Mesh with SAP Cloud Application Event Hub

The latest updates allow you to connect your SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh system to SAP Cloud Application Event Hub for the consumption and exposure of events.

SAP Cloud Application Event Hub creates a clear, user-friendly, and adaptable way to easily exchange business events across SAP's cloud landscape. The solution is a key part of SAP's event-driven architecture. With the integration, you can access events from various SAP business systems, published via the hub, directly on SAP Integration Suite's advanced event mesh.

Migration & Modernization

ABAP proxy generation from service interfaces for current users of SAP Process Orchestration

SAP Integration Suite now supports the implementation of existing use cases for the Enterprise Services Repository using an efficient API-first development methodology. This assists users in importing the service interface artifacts from their PI/PO systems to the Cloud Integration workspace. The feature includes the ability to generate and update ABAP Proxies (non-language-specific interface descriptions in Web Services Description Language converted into executable interfaces) in SAP backend or S/4 HANA systems by connecting them to the SAP Integration Suite tenant and it’s available in the multi-cloud environment. Find more details and the prerequisites here.

Migration assessment: Clean core modernization recommendations for BAPIs

This extension of the Migration Assessment capability in SAP Integration Suite makes it possible for users to analyse used BAPIs in SAP Process Orchestration. Additionally, they receive recommendations available in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to transition from legacy content and adopt a clean core approach, e.g. replacing RFCs (BAPIs) with SOAP/OData APIs, IDOCs with Business Events, Alert Rules by SAP Cloud ALM, and more. Explore all modernization recommendations covered in each area.

Dive Deeper

New learning offerings available

Accelerating Hybrid Integrations with SAP Integration Suite on RedHat OpenShift Set up, deploy, and run an Edge Integration Cell on Red Hat OpenShiftTime investment 3h, Record of achievement
